prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J0224
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: sources: J0224-3508, J0224-3469, J0224-3414, J0224-11, J0224-12, J0224-3379, J0224-3483, J0224-43 centered on J0224-3379; with average redshift of the 8 members; expected peak flux is for weakest source we expect to detect (J0224-3379)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Each science goal corresponds to the single pointing in each cluster field. The technical justification is the same for each science goal. We have therefore split the technical justification into three sections, with one in each science goal: spectral setup; sensitivity calculation for CO(2-1); and continuum sensitivity.
Spectral Setup: In order to best probe the total molecular gas, we have chosen the lowest CO line transition possible for z=1.6: CO(2-1) at 87.7GHz, corresponding to Band 3. We note that z=1.7 is the highest possible redshift at which to detect CO(2-1) with Cycle 2. In order to simultaneously observe line emission and maximize continuum sensitivity, we choose the FDM correlator mode for one baseband with a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and dual polarization to detect CO, and use the TDM mode for the remaining three basebands. Based on CO studies of similar populations (D10) we expect our line widths to span a FWHM of ~200-600km/s. Our redshift uncertainties are ~0.001, corresponding to 115km/s at z=1.6. Therefore the spectral window for the CO detection (6414 km/s) is sufficient to fully cover our line profiles and redshift uncertainties. Moreover, our target redshifts only vary by z<0.014 (1600 km/s) allowing us to implement a single spectral tuning and still hit all the targets within the large spectral window of 6414 km/s.
To maximize our sensitivity for detection of the CO(2-1) emission line, we request the most compact configuration, which provides an angular resolution of 4.3 arcsec in Band 3. At z=1.5, D10 find spatial extents of 6-11 kpc for the CO(2-1) emission, corresponding to 0.7-1.3 arcsec. Our proposed resolutions are therefore coarse enough that we should not resolve emission from any of our sources. We also note that our closest sources are separated by 4.7 arcsec, which is larger than one beam away and therefore we will not suffer from blended sources (see simulations in Figure 2). Moreover, the FOV at 88 GHz (FWHM of 70 arcsec) allows us to target multiple cluster members in a single pointing; simulations reveal that our more massive sources close to the edge of the primary beam (e.g. 30 arcsec away) are still robustly detected at high S/N despite the fall-off in sensitivity of the beam.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J0330
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: sources: J0330-3193, J0330-2968, J0330-2825, J0330-2876a, J0330-2876b centered just west of J0330-2968 with average redshift of the 5 members; expected peak flux is for weakest source we expect to detect (J0330-2825)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity Calculation for CO(2-1): The commonly-used correlation between FIR luminosity and CO line luminosity (S05) is based on observations of local ULIRGs and spirals, and on the most active high-z systems, primarily SMGs and quasars, which typically have high SF efficiencies. As there are only a handful of CO studies in less-active, star-forming galaxies at higher redshifts, we instead estimate our CO line luminosity based on the evolution of the molecular gas fraction in similar mass-limited samples to our own. Essentially, this allows us to investigate differences in the gas fractions rather than pre-selecting by SF efficiency.
We calculate our expected CO line flux assuming a FWHM of 400km/s and thermalized CO emission; this is warranted given the results from A10 who detected CO(1-0) emission in the z=1.5 BzK galaxies from D10 and found that on average the gas was thermalized up to J=2. Even if we do assume sub-thermalized emission with a brightness temperature ratio of 0.85 (D09), our gas and stellar mass limits only increase to 3e10Msol and 5e10Msol, respectively.
Based on the evolution of the molecular gas fraction (see Figure 1), we expect our stellar mass-limited sample, at z=1.6, to contain total gas fractions >40%, as this is a lower limit for SF galaxies of these masses at our redshift. We assume a gas mass-to-L' conversion of alpha=3.0, which is between a ULIRG and Galactic scaling, and consistent with similar studies (D10). The final calculation is as follows: we compute the expected gas mass, given our stellar mass limit and minimum assumed gas fraction, and convert to L'(CO) using the aforementioned alpha conversion and line brightness ratio. This corresponds to a peak flux of 0.65 mJy/beam, based on the cluster redshifts, observed emission line frequency (88GHz), and line width (400km/s). We aim for a robust line detection with S/N>4 (this will likely be higher given our rather conservative assumptions), and 100 km/s (29 MHz) channels to sufficiently sample the line width (>4 binned channels, but we can bin finer for bright CO detections), which dictates our desired rms sensitivity of 0.16 mJy/beam. This will require ~1.6 hours integration time per pointing, and ~3.1 hours including overheads, yielding a total of 9.3 hours for all three pointings assuming the maximum pwv (7th Octile, 5.2 mm).
We also emphasize that with 100 km/s channels, we should have a sufficient measure of the line width for the the broader profiles, and thus a handle on the dynamical mass of the system. As we have accurate spectroscopic redshifts for all the targets, we can stack any CO non-detections to calculate a lower limit of molecular gas content for systems with small gas fractions. Furthermore, blind CO detections of cluster members within the large FOV (600 kpc at z=1.6) are certainly possible given the large bandwidth in redshift space (z= 0.056).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J0225
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: sources: J0225-3303, J0225-3102, J0225-2965 centered just north of J0225-3102; with average redshift of the 3 members; expected peak flux is for weakesst source we expect to detect (J0225-2965)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Continuum Sensitivity: We have designed our spectral set-up to provide continuum measurements in the three remaining basebands, yielding a total bandwidth of 5.625GHz plus the line-free regions of the CO(2-1) baseband. As our primary aim is to detect the molecular gas, the integration time required to reach our rms sensitivity for CO dictates the achievable continuum sensitivity of 0.012 mJy/beam at 3.1 mm. This corresponds to ULIRG-level luminosities. We will therefore only use this measurement as an upper-limit in most cases, or stack the continuum flux for all cluster members. However, if we do detect any 3.1 mm flux, we can use it in tandem with public Herschel-SPIRE data from HerMES to estimate spectral indices and separate dust-dominated sources from AGNs with synchrotron emission (e.g. V10), as well as constrain the dust temperature of cluster galaxies. Moreover, we can follow-up any non-detections at 450um with a future ALMA call, as probing below 100 Msol/yr at z=1.6 will become increasingly easy with the addition of telescopes.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose Band 3 observations for a stellar mass-limited sample of spectroscopically-confirmed cluster galaxies to detect CO(2-1) for the first time within z=1.6 massive cluster environments. CO(2-1) traces the total molecular gas reservoir that fuels star formation (SF), allowing us to place the first constraints on the evolution of the gas fraction within the highest density regions at z=1.6. This epoch marks the peak in the integrated SF of the Universe, and the pivotal point when SF migrates to cluster cores. Comparing CO within cluster galaxies to the field at z~1.5 will help us address the crucial question: what governs SF over cosmic time and in various environments? We target 3 massive spectroscopically-confirmed clusters (54 members) from the SpARCS survey, which has so far returned ~20 high-z clusters. With a minimum of 11-16 detections, we expect to more than double the current sample of CO measurements in cluster environments in 9.3 hours total. All 3 clusters have also been granted Cycle 21 HST time (16 orbits) for additional spectroscopy and imaging. This redshift represents the most distant epoch at which it is possible detect the CO(2-1) transition with Cycle 2.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: The SpARCS collaboration is submitting another proposal (PI Ricardo Demarco, "'Mass growth at high-z: molecular gas and dust in the core of a galaxy cluster at z=1.63" with project code 2013.1.00463.S) that is targeting sources in J0224: one of the clusters proposed for here. It aims to detect CO(5-4), CO(3-2), CO(2-1), and Band 7 continuum. The 2-1 transistion in 2013.1.00463.S will be retracted if both proposals are accepted. We note that these proposals are not dependent on eachother and have very different science goals. We are also submitting 2013.1.01000 (PI: van Kampen) which aims to detect CO3-2 and continuum band 7 in galaxy pairs within J0330; the science goals are therefore very different.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: A Cycle 1 proposal was submitted (PI Allison Noble, code 2012.1.00491.S) with similar science goals but aimed to detect CO(2-1) in a smaller sample of only two galaxy clusters.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
